Topics include: Reviewing innovative approaches to the study of host-microbiome interactions; Implementation of novel methods for the study of evolutionary demographics in populations using genomic data; Identifying signatures of selection mediated by pathogens and the environment.
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to graduate students; qualified undergraduates may enroll with permission of instructor.
courses.BIOE 281N — Topics in Marine Vertebrate:
Course: BIOE 281N — Topics in Marine Vertebrate Ecology
Credits: 2
Description: Seminar on the ecology of marine vertebrates. Topics vary from the factors that explain the distribution of marine predators to island biogeography and the ecosystem effects of introduced vertebrates on islands.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.BIOE 281O — Topics in Plant-Water Relati:
Course: BIOE 281O — Topics in Plant-Water Relations
Credits: 2
Description: Intensive seminar focusing on fundamental and evolutionary concepts in plant-water relations. Students present results from their own research and discuss recent advances from the literature.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.BIOE 281P — Topics in Plant Population E:
Course: BIOE 281P — Topics in Plant Population Ecology
Credits: 2
Description: An intensive seminar on selected topics in plant ecology and population biology. Students present results from their own research and discuss recent advances from the literature.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.BIOE 281Q — Topics in Molecular Evolutio:
Course: BIOE 281Q — Topics in Molecular Evolutionary Genetics
Credits: 2
Description: An intensive seminar on selected topics in molecular evolutionary genetics. Students are required to present results from their own research projects, present a critical review paper at least once during the quarter, and submit a written research proposal.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.BIOE 281R — Topics in Marine Ecology and:
Course: BIOE 281R — Topics in Marine Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
Credits: 2
Description: An intensive seminar series focusing on fundamental concepts in marine ecology. Emphasis changes quarter to quarter. At least one quarter per year is devoted to discussion of graduate student research. Other quarters involve reading and evaluating current and classic literature on marine ecology and evolutionary biology.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.BIOE 281S — Topics in Ancient DNA and Pa:
Course: BIOE 281S — Topics in Ancient DNA and Paleogenomics
Credits: 2
Description: Topics in population genetics and genomics, focusing on work involving paleontological and archaeological material. Students present weekly written and oral reports of their research projects. Once each term, students critique a recent publication.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.BIOE 281T — Topics in Evolutionary Devel:
Course: BIOE 281T — Topics in Evolutionary Developmental Biology
Credits: 2
Description: Centers on reading and discussion of selected publications along with peer review of research plans, grant proposals, manuscripts, lectures, and conference presentations. The overarching goal is to support the development and progress of graduate students in the Ecology and Evolutionary Biology Department whose thesis work and interests align with the course topics. Topics include: reviewing advances in the field of regeneration; applications of novel techniques in functional genomics; and comparative genomics in evolution, development, and regeneration. (Formerly Species Interactions and Coevolution.)
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.BIOE 281U — Topics in Invertebrate Biolo:
Course: BIOE 281U — Topics in Invertebrate Biology
Credits: 2
Description: An intensive study about concepts, theory, and techniques for graduate students conducting research on the ecology, genetics, evolution, systematics, or biodiversity of marine invertebrates.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.BIOE 281V — Topics in Behavioral Ecology:
Course: BIOE 281V — Topics in Behavioral Ecology
Credits: 2
Description: A discussion of current topics in behavioral ecology including social information use, conceptual advances in understanding the evolution of animal signaling, and using a mechanistic approach to infer ecological processes from soundscapes.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.BIOE 281W — Topics in Exercise and Envir:
Course: BIOE 281W — Topics in Exercise and Environmental Physiology
Credits: 2
Description: A weekly seminar discussion on current research and techniques in mammalian exercise and environmental physiology. Areas covered include locomotor physiology, exercise testing and cardiovascular monitoring, and biomechanics. Oral presentation of ongoing research or current literature required from each student.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.BIOE 281X — Topics in Behavioral Ecology:
Course: BIOE 281X — Topics in Behavioral Ecology of Large Marine Vertebrates
Credits: 2
Description: Weekly seminar course centering on reading and discussion of selected publications along with peer review of research plans, grant proposals, manuscripts, lectures, and conference presentations. The overarching goal is to support the development and progress of graduate students in the Ecology and Evolutionary Biology Department whose thesis work and interests align with the course topic (reviewing innovative approaches in marine mammal science, coupling physiological with ecological concepts using integrative tools, identifying ecological and evolutionary context of large marine vertebrate research).
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.BIOE 281Y — Topics in Climate Change Bio:
Course: BIOE 281Y — Topics in Climate Change Biology
Credits: 2
Description: This weekly seminar course centers on reading and discussing of selected publications along with peer review of research plans, grant proposals, manuscripts, lectures, and conference presentations. Students support the development and progress of graduate students in the Ecology and Evolutionary Biology Department whose thesis work and interests align with the course topics including: reviewing impacts of extreme climate events, inferring microevolutionary processes from genomic time series, and understanding community composition change in marine ecosystems.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.BIOE 281Z — Conservation Science in a Ch:
Course: BIOE 281Z — Conservation Science in a Changing World
Credits: 2
Description: Selected readings and guest speakers in conservation, climate science and the ecology of environmental change coupled with peer review of participants' research proposals, grant proposals, manuscripts and scientific presentations.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.BIOE 286 — Experimental Design and Data:
Course: BIOE 286 — Experimental Design and Data Analysis
Credits: 5
Description: Focuses on problems and designs in ecology and population biology. Topics include experimental design; exploratory data analysis; hands-on statistics; and graphical theory. Structured around a statistical analysis and graphics program to teach students to design surveys and experiments and analyze data. Previous work in statistics strongly recommended.
Requirements: Requirements Concurrent enrollment in BIOE 286L is required. Enrollment is restricted to graduate students.
courses.BIOE 286L — Experimental Design and Data:
Course: BIOE 286L — Experimental Design and Data Analysis Lab
Credits: 2
Description: Lab will focuses on hands-on statistical problem solving, graphical presentations and experimental design issues.
Requirements: Requirements Concurrent enrollment in BIOE 286 is required. Enrollment is restricted to graduate students.
courses.BIOE 294 — Ecology, Evolutionary Biology:
Course: BIOE 294 — Ecology, Evolutionary Biology Seminar
Credits: 0
Description: Selected topics of current interest to ecologists and evolutionary biologists presented by weekly guest speakers.
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to graduate students.
courses.BIOE 297A — Independent Study:
Course: BIOE 297A — Independent Study
Credits: 5
Description: Independent study for graduate students who have not yet settled on a research area for their thesis. Students submit petition to sponsoring agency.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.BIOE 297B — Independent Study:
Course: BIOE 297B — Independent Study
Credits: 10
Description: Independent study for graduatestudents who have not yet settled on a research area for their thesis. Students submit petition to sponsoring agency.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes

Course: BIOE 297C — Independent Study
Credits: 15
Description: Independent study for graduate students who have not yet settled on a research area for their thesis. Students submit petition to sponsoring agency.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.BIOE 297F — Independent Study:
Course: BIOE 297F — Independent Study
Credits: 2
Description: Independent study for graduate students who have not yet settled on a research area for their thesis. Students submit petition to sponsoring agency. Enrollment is restricted to graduate students.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.BIOE 299A — Thesis Research:
Course: BIOE 299A — Thesis Research
Credits: 5
Description: Students submit petition to sponsoring agency.

courses.BIOE 299B — Thesis Research:
Course: BIOE 299B — Thesis Research
Credits: 10

courses.BIOE 299C — Thesis Research:
Course: BIOE 299C — Thesis Research

courses.ECON 272 — Evolutionary Game Theory:
Course: ECON 272 — Evolutionary Game Theory
Credits: 5
Description: Reviews static equilibrium concepts, games of incomplete information, and the traditional theory of dynamic games in discrete time. Develops recent evolutionary game models, including replicator and best reply dynamics, and applications to economics, computer science, and biology. Prerequisite(s): upper-division math courses in probability theory are strongly recommended. Cannot receive credit for this course and ECON 166B or CSE 166B.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.PHIL 246 — Ethics, Nature, and Natural S:
Course: PHIL 246 — Ethics, Nature, and Natural Selection
Credits: 5
Description: Explores the role, if any, that Darwinian theory and evolutionary biology should have on ethical theory. Topics range from classic work, including Darwin and classic expositors, to influential contemporary work on natural selection, in light of the best philosophical literature.
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to graduate students.
courses.SCIC 160 — Introduction to Science Writi:
Course: SCIC 160 — Introduction to Science Writing
Credits: 5
Description: A rigorous examination and practice of the skills involved in writing articles about science, health, technology, and the environment for the general public. Covers the essential elements of news writing and explanatory journalism, including developing a story idea, interviewing scientists, fact checking, composition, and editing of multiple drafts about scientific research.
Requirements: Requirements Prerequisite(s): satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and C1, C2 requirements. Enrollment is restricted to junior and senior physical and biological sciences majors.
